bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, January 19, 1941

div1.p: Hench gently chides Hutchison for omitting to send the promised autographed pictures of Kissinger and Moran. Hench requests additional copies of "A Milestone." He also solicits fundraising advice for a planned memorial in Havana, Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, January 19, 1941
div1.p:
You are no better than I am! Your letter says, “Enclosed are pictures
from Kissinger and Moran...” but obviously they weren't enclosed, and I imagine that
your wiser secretary sent them by separate post. Nuts to you, and again nuts! You
say, “About the time you get them replaced the others will turn up somewhere.” Again
a thousand nuts! Apparently you still don't believe that I sent them. I have a definite
memorandum in my own handwriting, attached to the empty envelope, in which these pictures
were, and the memo plainly reads, “Autographed photographs of Kissinger and Moran sent
to W. and J.” However, all's well that ends well.

I am delighted to know that you had such a swell trip to California.
I wish that I felt as assured of heaven as you do. If I did, I would do more flying.
My secretary fears that if I should fall, I would keep on going straight on through to
the hot region, and I fear she knows me so well that she may be right!

I am glad you gave me an excuse for not having written to thank you for
the swell Christmas present. It took me several days to recover from the holiday festivi-
ties and when I was about to write you, you wrote and said you were off to California!
Seriously, the plates were swell and nothing would have pleased us more. Mary was de-
lighted also, and they fit beautifully with the others. We have planned to fill out
your Lafayette set of plates but none are yet available. We will keep that in mind for
a later gift.

And now for another request. I am sorry I didn't know you planned to
print my address in your brochure “A Milestone”. It was my understanding that you were
not going to print it anywhere. Had I known it, I would have asked to see proof, and
checked over the manuscript a little more carefully. As it is, there are three slight
mistakes: “Epidemiologic” was spelled “epidemiologic”, “Pogolotti” was misspelled
“Pogolotti” and by a slip of the pencil on my part, I quoted Truby as saying that Lazear
got sick on August 16, which should have been September 16. However, these are minor
errors and will be corrected when I publish it in a medical journal sometime. I
thought the brochure was grand. You say you had five thousand printed. I am wondering
if there is any possible chance of my getting a generous number. I find that I have a
list of almost seventy-five individuals (physicians, librarians, army people in Cuba,
Washington and elsewhere in this country) who have given me material assistance in my
investigations over the last two years. A great majority of them specifically requested
a copy of my W. and J. talk, and I vaguely promised to send them one. Is there any
possibility that you could send me (don't faint!) a hundred copies of the brochure and
a hundred copies of the November, 1940 Alumni Bulletin? I would be certainly very glad
to send these to the people who have been so helpful, and I think it would be an ex-
cellent advertisement for W. and J. If you will express them to me, I will be delighted
to send them out from here and save you about $10.00 postage, particularly because I want
to write at least a one or two line note with each one, and will also correct the errors
noted above. You may think that the Alumni Bulletin obviates the necessity of sending
the brochure. I think they are both complementary and will show these earnest friends
of Lazear's and Reed's what W. and J. really thought of Lazear, and did about it at the
ceremony. Of these hundred copies, I would like to send about ten to personal friends.
The rest, as I have said, are to go to those who have materially helped me in my investi-
gation.

Will you tell me Mr. Pew's full name and address? How did he receive
you when you visited him on behalf of Moran's expenses? Do you think that I could
approach him sometime in the future for a contribution toward our memorial, seeing
as how their local co-worker and Cuban representative took such a prominent part in
the venture. I, personally, would think that a contribution from Pew in behalf of
this memorial in Havana would be darned good business. I am going to Havana in March
to try and finish up the details and get the property signed, sealed and delivered,
and discuss the question of the memorial--the type it should be, the cost, etc.---
with the Minister of Defense. After a couple of weeks there in March, we will
rest the first two weeks in April at Palm Beach.

Did you send the brochure to Mrs. Lazear and her relatives? Did you
send her a plate, as you once said you thought you would do? If not, I would like
the privilege of sending a plate of the Lazear Memorial Building to Mrs. Lazear,
with my own personal compliments. She was so nice to me that I want to “salve her
up.” If you haven't sent it, please consider this an order, send it to her, and
I will send you a check and write to her that it is on the way, in my name.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
